occurs when a stable point collides with an unstable point; when crossing a tipping point induces hysteresis

When the recovery rate (time to return) of a system decreases (approaches zero) as a system approaches a critical point (possibly a threshold or tipping point). A characteristic observed in some empirical systems data (e.g. nutrient loading in shallow lakes).
The parameter values for a system that causes the system to shift between alternate attractors.
The set of values towards which a system tends
An attractor which has fractal structure (an observable fractal dimension).
The set of values around which a system revolves and does not change
An equilibrium is stable when small perturbations do not induce change
An equilibrium is unstable when small perturbations induce change.
A system with extreme sensitivity to initial conditions.

column2: A value that conveys the average rate of trajectory divergence that is caused by an endogenous force; how quickly (if at all) a system will tend away from a stable point if it starts near the stable point.
A measurement of geometrical self-similarity; when a system has similar structure regardless of the scale of observation
A system satisfied by  power-law scaling
A system which is state-dependent (e.g. magnets); when a tipping point or threshold is crossed such that the previous state cannot be achieved by reversing the conditions.
A perturbation which negatively influences a system, and can be defined as pulse, press, or monotonic.
A widespread anthropogenic source of change which leads to one or more pressures (e.g., land-use change).
The number of system parameters or components which vary independently
A temporal forecast. Is intrinsic when a model and paramters are used to make forecast, is realized when the prediction becomes the actual state of the system.
